summary.seg: This manuscript contains Hero's Pneumatica, a treatise about devices worked by compressed air, steam, and water. The work is commonly attributed to Hero of Alexandria (1st c. CE), Greek engineer, inventor, and mathematician.

The book seems to have been a gift to Ernest of Bavaria (1554-1612), who was bishop of Freising (1566), Hildesheim (1573), and Liège (1581), abbot of Stavelot-Malmedy (1581), archbishop and prince-elector of Cologne (1583), and bishop of Münster (1585). There is a dedication letter to him at the beginning of the manuscript by Josephus Auria (Giuseppe d'Auria), Italian mathematician from Naples, who was active between the second half of the 16th century and the beginning of the 17th.

The manuscript was copied by Ioannes Mauromates, Greek scribe from Corfu, who was active in Italy - specifically, in Venice, Rome, Florence and Bologna - in the second half of the 16th century (see RGK I, 171, Cataldi Palau (2000)). He probably copied this manuscript while he was in Rome in the years 1555-1573 (see Cataldi Palau (2000), p. 377). Mauromates copied Hero's Pneumatica in three other manuscripts, while he was in Rome in the years 1548-1552/53 ( Cataldi Palau (2000), pp. 375-376):
Roma, Biblioteca Angelica, gr. 109
Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Suppl. gr. 11
London, British Library, Harley MS 5605.

msItem.title: Dedication to Ernest of Bavaria, signed by Giuseppe d'Auria
msItem.rubric: f. ii recto Ad illustrissimum principem Hernestum comitem Palatinum Rheni utriusque Bavariae ducem, administratorem Frisingensem
msItem.incipit: f. ii recto Est ita profecto, Princeps illustrissime, quaemadmodum docti omnes
msItem.explicit: f. iii verso feliciter vivere sinat. Ex animo deditissimus servus Iosephus Auria

msItem.author: Hero of Alexandria
msItem.title: Pneumatica
msItem.incipit: f. 2:1r Τῆς πνευματικῆς πραγματείας σπουδῆς ἠξιωμένης
msItem.explicit: f. 2:44v καὶ τηνικαῦτα προσενεχθέντος αὐτῷ ποτηρίου, πίεται.
msItem.note: Throughout the text, blank spaces have been left for diagrams, which follow the text, traced only on the recto of the leaves
On f. i recto there is a title in Latin: Heronis Alexandrini spiritalium libri duo Graeci manuscripti numquam adhuc neque Latini impressi

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: f. 1:1-1:12, i-iii, 2:48-2:57, 2:59-2:68 Crescent ( 27 29 ), in the centre of the leaf , comparable to Briquet Croissant 5212, 5213 , which are dated in 1566 and 1580 (Italy).
ff. 2:1r-2:32v Anchor in a circle surmounted by a six-point star ( 72 45 ), in the centre of the leaf , comparable to Sosower Ancre 27 , which is dated in 1569 (Rome).
ff. 2:33-2:46 Paschal lamb in a circle ( 47 45 ), in the centre of the leaf , identical to Sosower Agneau pascal 1 , which is dated to 1569 (Rome).
ff. 2:47/2:58, 2:69-2:75 Eagle in a circle surmounted by a crown ( 62 45 ), in the centre of the leaf , very similar to Sosower Aigle 10 , which is dated ca. 1551-1559.

supportDesc.foliation:
The manuscript is foliated in modern pencil, in Arabic and Roman numerals, in the upper right corner of the leaves:
12 blank leaves at the beginning of the manuscript are numbered 1-12
3 leaves containing a dedication letter are numbered i-iii
the remaining leaves are numbered 1-75. The foliation is: 1:1-1:12 + i-iii + 2:1-2:75.

collation.p: The manuscript consists mainly of quaternions.

list.item: Quire 118-1 ff. 2:69-2:75 (1st leaf missing, no loss of text)

signatures.p: On ff. 2:1r-2:41r, on the upper edge, centre, of the first leaf of each quire, there are small crosses, in brown or red ink, traced by the scribe (it is a known practice of Ioannes Mauromates, see Cataldi Palau (2000), p. 368).

On ff. iii verso-2:41r there are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, written in brown ink on the quires' first leaf, upper right, and on the last leaf, upper left (2 consecutive numbers per quire), from 2 ( f. iii verso) to 1[5] ( f. 2:47r).

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in good condition.

handNote.p: ff. 2:1r-2:44v Hand A: the text has been written entirely by Ioannes Mauromates (active 16th century, mid-3rd quarter) Mauromates, Ioannes (active 16th century, mid-3rd quarter) , (Ἰωάννης Μαυρομάτης, RGK I, 171. See also RGK II, 229; RGK III, 283).
The text is written in brown ink; titles and initials in red.
ff. 2:47r-2:63r Hand B: another hand wrote the titles and final rubrics to the diagrams, which were probably also traced by this scribe. The script is a minuscule, vertical, datable in the 16th c.

handDesc.handNote: ff. i recto-iii verso Hand C: another hand wrote in Latin the dedication to Ernest of Bavaria, in a humanistic minuscule script. The text is written in brown ink, the title is written in gold with initials in blue and red ink, minor initials in the text are traced in gold and Greek words in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: In the manuscript are distinguishable two different types of decoration: a floral decoration in gold and green, blue, red ink for the dedication letter to Ernest of Bavaria; a more modest decoration in red ink by Ioannes Mauromates for the Greek text.

F. i recto , title-page: a floral rectangular border in gold, green, blue and red surrounds a Latin title written in gold, with initials in blue, red, black and green, Heronis Alexandrini spiritalium libri duo Graeci manuscripti numquam adhuc neque Latini impressi. In the centre of the lower part of the frame is depicted the coat of arms of the Electorate of Bavaria.

The dedication to Ernest of Bavaria on f. ii recto is preceded by a headpiece with the same type of floral decoration in green, blue and red ink of the title-page (f. i recto). The title is written in gold, with initials in blue and red ink.
On f. ii recto there is an initial in gold, on a square ground with red penwork ornament.
On f. 2:1r there is a linear undulated frieze with clovers at both ends.
Thick red penwork initials with a vegetal ornament, see e.g. f. 2:1r.
On ff. 2:47r-2:63r there are diagrams illustrating Heron's work.

additions.p: The manuscript's shelfmark is written on the left pastedown, and on f. i recto .
On f. 1:2r there are some annotations referring to the manuscript's numbers and shelfmarks: G 31 (old shelfmark), n° 287 (previous number), O. 4. 9 (present shelfmark).

binding.p:
Western binding, contemporary to the production of the manuscript. Full red morocco cover over pasteboards. Gold tooled borders on boards, decorated with geometrical motifs, lilies in correspondence of the external edges, a vegetal motif in the edges of the internal rectangle; at the centre of the left cover gold tooled medallion. Gold tooling on spine, where are pasted three paper labels with the shelfmark (the second is damaged), O,
, 9. The holes for leather ties are present on both boards, one hole in the centre of the upper and lower part, 2 holes on the external part of the boards. Gold tooling on the boards' edges. Gauffered gilded edges. 342 225 30
binding.condition: There are some scraps on the cover.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Ioannes Mauromates between the middle and the 3rd quarter of the 16th century. The watermarks, present also in other manuscripts copied by Mauromates, the codicological features, and some characteristics of the script enable the dating of this manuscript to a particular stage of the scribe's life: he probably copied the manuscript in Rome between December 1555 and 1573 (for this dating and the characteristics of Mauromates' production, see Cataldi Palau (2000), pp. 377-379).

history.provenance: The manuscript was donated by the Italian mathematician Giuseppe d'Auria to Ernest, of Bavaria, Archbishop and Elector of Cologne, 1554-1612 Ernest of Bavaria (1554–1612) : see dedication on ff. ii recto-iii verso. The donation probably took place around the last quarter of the 16th century: it is known that Giuseppe d'Auria was active in the years 1587-1602 (see RGK II, 289).
history.acquisition:
The manuscript was donated to the Library by the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744
in 1738 ( James 1902, p. xxiv). On the lower part of f. i verso is pasted the Trinity College bookplate; above, there is Trinity College Libary's stamp.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1902), vol. 3, pp. 257-258.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
